title: Analysis of Psychomotor Language Learning Effects Under Cannabis Influence: State-Dependent Learning Design and Language Processing Strategies

context.prior_knowledge: Basic pharmacological knowledge, psychomotor learning theories, and foundational linguistic concepts (grammar, vocabulary, text analysis, speech act theory)
context.additional_context: Learners analyze changes in language performance under medication influence and derive practical language learning insights through project outputs. Conducts language data analysis practice using personal devices in BYOD environments, with customized feedback systems for improving expressive and reading skills.

learning_goals: Quantitatively compare differences in psychomotor performance and language information processing (lexical recall, sentence construction, grammatical structure analysis) between drug-influenced and non-influenced states.

Learners apply state-dependent learning design principles (e.g., scheduling language learning materials according to medication timing) to create an experimental design measuring learning effectiveness under drug influence (vocabulary memorization accuracy, grammatical structure recall speed, text analysis efficiency) and derive results meeting ≥3 evaluation criteria (e.g., ≥80% vocabulary accuracy, ≥20% improvement in grammatical recall speed, ≥15% enhancement in text analysis accuracy).

Over a 6-month course, learners produce project reports applying language learning strategies (2 text analysis methods: semantic structure/pragmatic analysis; 2 expression optimization methods: lexical selection/sentence structure adjustment) under 3 drug conditions (e.g., ADHD medication, antidepressants, sedatives) and achieve ≥3.5 average scores on peer/teacher evaluations (5-point scale).
difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
